Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Telehealth and Wellness for Senior Citizens Utilizing In-Home Gigabit HD Multipoint Videoconferencing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
High-Definition Multipoint Videoconferencing is a core application for Gigabit and faster networks. Commercial systems, designed for 10 megabit and slower networks, employ expensive conferencing bridges that have to be managed, limit the number of concurrent video conferences, and limit the quality of the video. In this research project, the endpoints discover and exchange their capabilities and determine the usable network bandwidth between them to negotiate parameters for the best quality video conference. Since the video conferences are established between two or more endpoints directly, the solution is scalable. And since no conferencing bridge is used, the solution is affordable. By taking advantage of the Gigabit or faster network bandwidth, the endpoints can send reduced-compression video or uncompressed video that is higher quality than that offered by current systems. In GENI-enabled networks, layer 2 routing is used to increase effective bandwidth and GENI slices are used for enhanced privacy.

The Case Connection Zone, a Gigabit fiber-to-the-home research project of Case Western Reserve University, is demonstrating how the Gigabit network can be used to improve quality of life for the residents in several national priority areas, including health and wellness. Next generation HD multipoint video conferencing is an essential tool for several initiatives. In about 200 senior residences, it enables seniors, without leaving home, to consult clinicians, participate in chronic disease support groups, in social groups, and in lifelong learning. Many Gigabit applications will incorporate this technology or be built upon it.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have created Connected Collaboration, a game-changing videoconferencing technology that uses a gigabit network and commodity computers, cameras and microphones to exchange high definition video and high fidelity audio. In its current state, Connected Collaboration works between two endpoints comprising two Windows computers, two Macintosh computers, or one Windows computer and one Macintosh computer. We recommend using a commodity 1080p webcam such as a Logitech C-920, and a good microphone such as an MXL AC404 USB Conference Microphone or a CAD U7 USB Desktop Condenser Recording Mic.

Connected Collaboration works between the endpoints without employing the MCUs or conferencing bridges typically used in high-end video conferencing and it uses the gigabit network to exchange higher resolution video and higher fidelity audio. Since there is no MCU or conferencing bridge, there is no need for a support staff, accounts, or scheduling.

Connected Collaboration is a core capability for many future gig apps including apps in the national priority areas identified in the National Broadband Plan: health and wellness, home energy management, public safety, STEM education at the high school level, advanced manufacturing, and economic development. Connected Collaboration is open source software and is freely available to other gig app developers.

Our goal for this grant was to develop Connected Collaboration and use it to connect senior citizens in their homes with their healthcare providers. We have begun this work and the initial results are encouraging. Both the providers and the seniors appreciate being able to resolve certain issues without requiring the senior to travel to the hospital, emergency room or doctor’s office. And proactive post discharge follow up has great potential for reducing hospital readmissions. By necessity, deploying Connected Collaboration to the seniors and their providers had to start after Connected Collaboration was functional and the gig network extended to each residence. This deployment is continuing beyond the end of the grant.
